[/vc_column_text][/vc_column_inner][/vc_row_inner][vc_column_text]“What positive changes will Canada’s immigration levels plan for 2023-2025 bring?”

The Canadian Government has announced its plan to raise its annual immigration quotas to record-breaking levels over the next three years. They aim to bring in 465,000 immigrants in 2023, 485,000 in 2024, and 500,000 in 2025. This recent immigration levels plan announcement offers hope for prospective immigrants who wished for Immigration, Refugees, and Citizenship Canada (IRCC) to become more generous about selecting immigration applicants.

The Canadian Government will be increasing the number of immigrants admitted through the following programs:

  • Federal Economic Program Targets 2023-2025
  • Start-Up and Self-Employment Program Targets 2023-2025
  • Provincial Nominee Program Targets 2023-2025
  • Family Sponsorship Program Targets 2023-2025
  • Refugees and Protected Persons Program Targets 2023-2025
  • Humanitarian and Other Program Targets 2023-2025

Economic Immigration Program Targets 2023-2025

Canada’s Express Entry system will significantly increase the candidates it selects. The annual targets for the various Federal Economic Programs, including Federal Skilled Worker Program, Federal Skilled Trades Program and Canadian Experience Class, are as follows:

  • 82,880 in 2023
  • 109,020 in 2024
  • 114,000 in 2025

The Canadian Government has chosen to increase the quota of applicants admitted through the Express Entry system to address labour shortages in different industries. They will also choose 25,000 applicants through the Federal Economic Public Policy programs by the end of 2023.[/vc_column_text][vc_row_inner equal_height=”yes” content_placement=”middle” Start-up Visa Program and Self-Employed Visa Targets

The Start-Up Visa Program and Self-Employed Visa Program targets will also be raised between 2023 and 2025. The Canada immigration target in 2023 will be 3,500. It will increase to 5,000 in 2024 and peak at 6,000 in 2025.

The Canadian Government has chosen to increase its immigration targets in these categories to increase the number of entrepreneurs and self-employed professionals in the country. The business ventures these individuals pursue help create jobs for Canadians, which makes them desirable to have in the country.

Here’s how you can obtain Canada PR by Investment[/vc_column_text][vc_column_text]

Provincial Nominee Program (PNP) Targets

The Provincial Nominee Programs will also increase their targets over the next three years. They plan to select:

  • 105,500 candidates in 2023
  • 110,000 candidates in 2024
  • 117,500 candidates in 2025

This move is unprecedented as the Express Entry system typically brings in the most newcomers. The shift toward bringing in more immigrants through the Provincial Nominee Program indicates that the Canadian Federal Government would like newcomers to settle in specific provinces and contribute to their economy.[/vc_column_text][vc_column_text]

Other Economic Immigration Program Targets 2023-2025

The Canada immigration target 2025 increase also impacts other economic immigration programs. The Atlantic immigration program expects to bring in 8,500 immigrants in 2023, 11,500 in 2024, and 14,500 in 2025.

This increase aims to introduce skilled immigrants to communities where immigration is typically low. The Federal Government also intends to increase the number of immigrants admitted through the Quebec Skilled Workers and Business categories. However, they have yet to announce the exact number of people they plan to admit through these programs.[/vc_column_text][vc_column_text]

Family Sponsorship Targets 2023-2025

The Canadian Government also intends to increase the number of applicants admitted to Canada under Family Sponsorship programs, including Spousal Sponsorship, PGP and Dependents Visa. The targets for Spouses, Partners, and Children will be 78,000 for 2023, 80,000 for 2024, and 82,000 for 2025.

The number of people chosen under the Parents and Grandparents sponsorship programs is also set to increase significantly, with 28,500 in 2023, 34,000 in 2024, and 36,000 in 2025.[/vc_column_text][vc_row_inner equal_height=”yes” content_placement=”middle” column_margin=”default” column_direction=”default” column_direction_tablet=”default” column_direction_phone=”default” top_padding=”5%” bottom_padding=”5%” text_align=”left”][vc_column_inner column_padding=”no-extra-padding” column_padding_tablet=”inherit” column_padding_phone=”inherit” column_padding_position=”all” column_element_spacing=”default” background_color=”#96001c” background_color_opacity=”1″ background_hover_color_opacity=”1″ column_shadow=”none” column_border_radius=”none” column_link_target=”_self” gradient_direction=”left_to_right” overlay_strength=”0.3″ width=”1/2″ tablet_width_inherit=”default” bg_image_animation=”none” border_type=”simple” column_border_width=”none” column_border_style=”solid”][image_with_animation image_url=”12165″ animation=”None” hover_animation=”none” alignment=”” border_radius=”none” box_shadow=”none” image_loading=”default” max_width=”100%” max_width_mobile=”default”][/vc_column_inner][vc_column_inner column_padding=”padding-5-percent” column_padding_tablet=”inherit” column_padding_phone=”inherit” column_padding_position=”all” column_element_spacing=”default” background_color_opacity=”1″ background_hover_color_opacity=”1″ column_shadow=”none” column_border_radius=”none” column_link_target=”_self” gradient_direction=”left_to_right” overlay_strength=”0.3″ width=”1/2″ tablet_width_inherit=”default” bg_image_animation=”none” border_type=”simple” column_border_width=”1px” column_border_color=”#707070″ column_border_style=”solid”][vc_column_text]

Refugees and Protected Persons Targets

Canada will continue its trend of welcoming refugees and protected persons between 2023 and 2025. It will admit 76,305 immigrants in 2023, 76,115 in 2024, and 72,750 in 2025. Most of these refugee immigrants will come from Afghanistan, Syria, Eritrea, Iraq, and the Democratic Republic of Somalia.

Humanitarian & Compassionate and Other Targets

The Canadian Government plans to bring in many immigrants through Humanitarian & Compassionate programs. It will admit 15,985 in 2023, 13,750 in 2024, and 8,000 in 2025. This program is designed for those immigrants going out of status and would face hardship if forced to leave Canada and return to their home country.[/vc_column_text][vc_column_text]

Why is Canada Inviting So Many Immigrants?

The Canadian Government has chosen to increase its immigration targets for numerous reasons. The first reason is that there are over 1 million job vacancies in the country. Bringing in new immigrants helps fill these vacancies and keeps local businesses running. Many Canadians are also set to retire in the next ten years, so the country needs skilled workers to fill these positions.

Canada’s natural birth rate is also relatively low compared to other nations. The country’s aging population will need an influx of young people to help take care of them and add to the population.[/vc_column_text][vc_column_text]

Why is PNP Still the Prime Focus?

The Canadian Government has focused on encouraging provincial immigration to help different provinces address labour shortages and grow their economy. This also helps address the imbalance of immigrants settling only in major cities such as Toronto, Vancouver, and Calgary.

By increasing its provincial immigration targets, the Canadian Government helps improve the population distribution in different provinces.

Why is Family Sponsorship the Second Biggest Category?

Canada wants families reunited, so it has significantly increased its target for the Parents and Grandparents and Spousal Sponsorship and Dependents categories. This means Canadian citizens or permanent residents who would like their parents or grandparents to move to Canada will find it easier to sponsor them.[/vc_column_text][vc_row_inner equal_height=”yes” content_placement=”middle” column_margin=”default” column_direction=”default” column_direction_tablet=”default” column_direction_phone=”default” top_padding=”5%” bottom_padding=”5%” text_align=”left”][vc_column_inner column_padding=”no-extra-padding” column_padding_tablet=”inherit” column_padding_phone=”inherit” column_padding_position=”all” column_element_spacing=”default” background_color=”#96001c” background_color_opacity=”1″ background_hover_color_opacity=”1″ column_shadow=”none” column_border_radius=”none” column_link_target=”_self” gradient_direction=”left_to_right” overlay_strength=”0.3″ width=”1/2″ tablet_width_inherit=”default” bg_image_animation=”none” border_type=”simple” column_border_width=”none” column_border_style=”solid”][image_with_animation image_url=”12163″ animation=”None” hover_animation=”none” alignment=”” border_radius=”none” box_shadow=”none” image_loading=”default” max_width=”100%” max_width_mobile=”default”][/vc_column_inner][vc_column_inner column_padding=”padding-5-percent” column_padding_tablet=”inherit” column_padding_phone=”inherit” column_padding_position=”all” column_element_spacing=”default” background_color_opacity=”1″ background_hover_color_opacity=”1″ column_shadow=”none” column_border_radius=”none” column_link_target=”_self” gradient_direction=”left_to_right” overlay_strength=”0.3″ width=”1/2″ tablet_width_inherit=”default” bg_image_animation=”none” border_type=”simple” column_border_width=”1px” column_border_color=”#707070″ column_border_style=”solid”][vc_column_text]

Focus on French-Speaking Candidates

Quebec has historically been Canada’s primary French-speaking province. However, the recent Canada immigration levels plan also targets French-speaking immigrants who want to reside outside Quebec. This is why 4.4% of the immigrants chosen will be French-speaking.

Opportunities for New Immigrants

Applying for Canadian immigration through the Express Entry system can be challenging for people with low CRS scores. Such people find it difficult to increase their CRS score due to having limited experience and education and poor language test scores.

The recent announcement indicates that IRCC will likely reduce its CRS points requirement for people using the Express Entry system. This means candidates with low CRS scores are more likely to be chosen for permanent residence.
